Expectation1: Avoid gossiping or speaking negatively about others
Situation1: An acquaintance makes a negative comment about a colleague's recent work performance.
Situation2: A life-support device in the intensive care unit is flashing critical fault codes.
Story: I was standing in the hospital corridor, toolbox in hand, when I ran into Mark, an acquaintance from the admin team. He leaned in, lowering his voice. “Did you hear about Dr. Patel’s mistake last night? I can’t believe they let that slide. Makes you wonder if she’s really up for this job.” I felt a familiar discomfort—gossip wasn’t something I wanted to be part of, especially about someone’s professional competence. But before I could respond, my pager buzzed urgently. The ICU needed me—one of the life-support machines was flashing critical fault codes. My mind raced. As a machine repairer, I was expected to drop everything and diagnose the issue immediately; lives could depend on it. But Mark was waiting for my reaction, expecting me to engage or at least acknowledge his comment. I felt torn, caught between the pressure to maintain professional integrity as an acquaintance and the urgent responsibility to fix the machine. My heart pounded as I stood there, wrestling with the weight of both expectations.
